Description: A terracotta mould for a pine cone, perhaps made from an actual example; there is no sign that there was a companion mould to make a whole fruit. Part is lost. Brown Nile silt with a grey-brown core and a little mica.
Curator's comments: Terracotta IV Donated: Egypt Exploration Fund. Excavated at Tanis, North West Hill, Find 30. A limestone utensil, the only other object from this find-spot mentioned by Favard-Meeks (1998: 154) is in the Boston Museum of Fine Arts, 86.200. Ptolemaic, perhaps third century BC. Comparanda: Similar mould from Athribis (My´sliwiec 1996b: pl. xii:1), dated to the third century BC; this one has the remains of a clay strap, indicating that a companion mould was extant. See also a mould from Medinet Habu, perhaps of the time of Rameses III (Hölscher 1951: pl. 37m); and a further mould in Hermann 1985: 124, no. 952. For a faience pine cone from Memphis, see Hilton Price 1897: 382, no. 3175. Bibliog: Favard-Meeks 1998: BM list:38291
Bibliographic references: Terracotta / Catalogue of Terracottas in the British Museum (3785)
